Graphical abstract A porous iron oxide-decorated 2D / 2D nanosheets of NiO and nitrogen-doped graphene facilitates charge transport and exposes formerly inaccessible reaction sites, maximizing active site density utilization, thereby improving electrocatalytic performance for ORR. As a noble metal substitute, two-dimensional (2D) hierarchical nano-frame structures have attracted great interest as candidate catalysts due to their remarkable advantages – high intrinsic activity, high electron mobility, and straightforward surface functionalization. Therefore, they may replace Pt-based catalysts in oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) applications. Herein, a simple method is developed to design hierarchical nano-frame structures assembled via 2D NiO and N-doped graphene (NG) nanosheets. This procedure can yield nanostructures that satisfy the criteria correlated with improved electrocatalytic performance, such as large surface area, numerous undercoordinated atoms, and high defect densities. Further, porous NG nanosheet architectures, featuring NiO nanosheets densely coordinated with accessible holey Fe2O3 moieties, can enhance mesoporosity and balance hydrophilicity. Such improvements can facilitate charge transport and expose formerly inaccessible reaction sites, maximizing active site density utilization. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations reveal favored O2 adsorption and dissociation on Fe2O3 hybrid structures when supported by 2D NiO and NG nanomaterials, given 2D materials donated charge to Fe2O3 active sites. Our systematic studies reveal that synergistic contributions are responsible for enriching the catalytic activity of Fe2O3@NiO / NG in alkaline media – encompassing internal voids and pores, unique hierarchical support structures, and concentrated N-dopant and bimetallic atomic interactions. Ultimately, this work expands the toolbox for designing and synthesizing highly efficient 2D / 2D shelled functional nanomaterials with transition metals, endeavoring to benefit energy conversion and related ORR applications. Keywords N-doped graphene Holey Fe2O3 nanocrystals NiO nanosheets High catalytic performance, ORR 1 Introduction ORR is a key consideration in fuel cell and metal–air battery cathode operation. This reaction requires active catalysts to achieve desired electronic properties. In addition, such catalysts should have high densities of reaction sites, strong electrochemical activity, and excellent stability within studied electrolytes [1,2]. Further, they should be synthesized using a reproducible procedure [3]. Thus, transition metal (M) oxide (M = Co, Fe, Ni) based nanostructures may meet these requirements [3–5] by substituting expensive Pt with M. Inexpensive mesoporous two-dimensiaonal (2D) nanostructures of nickel (Ni) oxides have desirable properties, such as high capacity, rate capability, and cycling stability [5–8]. Multiple accessible Ni valence states enable flexibility in redox reactions relative to other oxides [4,8]. Moreover, 2D layered Ni oxides [7,9] have been identified as energy storage candidates due to their low overpotentials and Tafel slopes. The ultra-high surface area of mesoporous 2D NiO exposes a large fraction of surface atoms to reactions, [10,11] and provides numerous active sites that improve catalytic reaction kinetics [12]. Furthermore, 2D NiO has hierarchical layered nanostructures that provide remarkable permeable channels for fast transportation and adsorption of ions. Such channels facilitate rapid electron transfer by accelerating catalytic reaction processes [13,14]. However, the interfaces of mesoporous NiO nanostructures can feature constrained close-packed basal planes. They yield high concentrations of valence-rich oxidized Ni states, which limit catalytic performance [15]. Controlling nanosheet thickness helps minimize diffusion path length, thereby ensuring rapid interfacial charge transport during electrocatalytic processes and thus optimizing catalytic performance. In addition, the number of defect-rich structures generally increases as 2D nanosheet thickness is reduced [16]. Such defects influence the physicochemical properties of these catalysts, and are linked to improvements in electrocatalytic performance [7,17]. Therefore, appropriate engineering of such properties could provide tremendous potential towards improving ORR catalytic activity. In this regard, defect engineering would provide suitable opportunities to exploit structure–property–performance relationships for rational catalyst design. Towards this end, numerous features including vacancies and interfacial facets could be controlled [3,17–20]. Usually, nanoscale NiO structures allow lattice deformations and surface dangling bonds, which increase the occurrence of structural defects [20]. Therefore, engineering of defects in 2D NiO should focus on activation of basal planes. Effective interactions between nanoscale NiO and highly conducting 2D carbonaceous supports can increase the concentrations of defects [5], including edge-defect sites, distorted surfaces, expanded structural pores, and grain boundaries [19–21]. Typically, amorphous transition metal oxides (TMOs) undergo huge volume changes and drastic structural reorganization during electrochemical processes. However, TMO structural components can be effectively maintained by integration with flexible and robust graphene supports [22], which improve TMO stability during electrochemical cycling. Further, NG nanostructures such as disordered/amorphous carbon networks provide the synergistic benefits of such interactions between catalyst and support [2,4,22]. Thus, hybridized NiO and NG nanosheet layers are strong candidates for the active basal planes of nanostructure surfaces [21,22]. Despite these advantages, amorphous 2D nanomaterials often suffer from active-site deficits that are caused by irreversible restacking of individual nanosheets, which inhibit ion storage and transport [22]. Incorporating metallic p-type holes in the p/n heterojunction interfaces of NiO / NG (2D / 2D) nanostructures can induce electrical conductivity. Such holes can be achieved by overcoming nanosheet aggregation [23]. Experimental results demonstrate that iron oxide (Fe2O3) serves multiple purposes, including modifying catalyst electronic structure to enhance electrocatalysis. Fe2O3 strongly increases the metallic character of nanostructures by shifting Fe 3d states towards the Fermi level. Furthermore, Fe2O3 improves the redox activity of the catalyst surface, which causes changes in active sites. This allows thermodynamically favorable oxygen adsorption on catalyst surfaces and lowers pertinent activation energies of oxygen adsorption [24]. Finally, the synergistic effects of hybridizing 2D NiO with Fe2O3 nanocrystals (NCs) are expected to develop highly active catalysts, which will deliver high rate capability and good recyclability. This article presents a simple two-step strategy to synthesize mesoporous Fe2O3@NiO-layered NG (Fe2O3@NiO / NG) hybrids as active catalysts for ORR. Given the combined advantages of ultrathin and defect-rich surfaces comprised of 2D nanosheets (NiO and NG) and porous Fe2O3 NCs, optimized Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrids exhibit remarkably high ORR activity and stability in alkaline media. Furthermore, oxygen vacancies are more easily formed in Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrid catalysts than in isolated 2D nanosheets, thus vacancies strongly enhance catalytic activity. Thereby, varying oxygen binding energies synergistically improves catalyst activity in association with Fe2O3 NCs, and accelerates catalytic charge transfer during ORR. By combining theoretical calculations with experimental studies, this work illuminates how atomic-scale defect engineering promotes electrocatalytic activity. This study also provides a way to design advanced electrocatalysts that have stable ORR performance. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemical reagents Graphite flake (<∼20 μm, synthetic), sulfuric acid (H2SO4, 99%), potassium permanganate (KMnO4, ≥∼99%), hydrogen peroxide (H2O2, ∼30%), hydrochloric acid (HCl, ∼35%), melamine (C3H6N6, >99.9%), ferric (ΙΙΙ) chloride hexahydrate (FeCl3·6H2O, >99.9%), nickel (ΙΙ) chloride hexahydrate (NiCl2·6H2O, >99.9%), ammonium hydroxide (NH4OH, 28.0% NH3 in H2O), and Nafion (0.05 wt. %) solutions were all purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Potassium hydroxide (KOH, ≥∼99.5%), ethanol (EtOH, ≥∼99.9%), methanol (MeOH, ≥∼99.9%), and carbon supported platinum (Pt/C, 20 wt.%) were received from Samchun Chemical Co. Ltd. (South Korea). Deionized (DI) water was distilled using a Steel Ace (SA-2100E1) filtering system from EYELA (Tokyo Rikakikai Co., Ltd., Japan). 2.2 Synthesis of graphene oxide (GO) and N-doped graphene (NG) Graphene oxide (GO) has been synthesized by Hummer’s method [25], as described in previous literature. To prepare NG, 50 mg of GO was first dispersed in 50 mL of DI water and ultrasonicated for 50 min. To the above highly dispersed GO solution, 250 mg of melamine was added and then stirred at 80 °C for 12 h. Then, the well mixed solution was dried completely and the obtained powder was finely grinded. Therefore, this fine powder was used for high temperature pyrolysis at 900 °C for 1 h under Ar gas flow to get NG nanosheets. 2.3 Synthesis of porous Fe2O3@NiO-layered NG (Fe2O3@NiO / NG) hybrids Porous hybrids of Fe2O3 enveloped in 2D NiO heterostructures (Fe2O3@NiO), which are wrapped in layered NG supports (Fe2O3@NiO / NG), were synthesized via an alkalization-assisted hydrothermal method followed by calcination. Synthesis proceeded firstly by mixing 1 mmol Ni salt and 2 mmol Fe salt in a dispersed NG solution, maintaining a suitable alkaline pH condition with sodium hydroxide (NaOH) addition. This homogenous solution was subjected to alkalization at ∼100 °C via a hydrothermal reaction with an ethanol and water mixture for 12 h. The result of alkalization was cooled down, washed, and neutralized by centrifugation with water and subsequently dried. The obtained powder was pyrolyzed for 3 h at ∼400–600 °C by varying temperature under an inert (Ar) atmosphere, and then cooled down to room temperature. The Fe2O3@NiO heterostructure without its support material (NG) was also prepared at ∼400 °C under similar experimental conditions for comparative purposes. Finally, each sample was collected and chemically leached into 0.5 M H2SO4 solution at ∼80 °C for 10 h, which removed unnecessary metallic reactants and impurities. Filtration ensued by repeated centrifugation with DI water, followed by drying at 60 °C under vacuum conditions. Following this procedure, the active studied ORR catalyst, or a porous Fe2O3@NiO-layered NG hybrid (Fe2O3@NiO / NG), was yielded. 2.4 Material characterization The morphological and structural characteristics of materials were investigated using field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) through a Supra 40 VP instrument (JEOL, JSM-7800F, FESEM-EDS). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-resolution TEM (HR-TEM) were carried out to examine the structures of materials in detail (JEOL, JEM-2200FS, HRTEM). X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was used to identify crystalline structures and chemical components using a D/Max 2500 V/PC (Rigaku Co., Japan) within a given 2θ range (10°–90°), and with Cu K α radiation (λ = 0.154 nm). The elemental compositions of catalysts were analyzed by inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES, Optima 8300; PerkinElmer Inc.). Using a thermal conductivity detector (BELJapanInc., BELCAT-M), H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was completed to measure the temperature and intensity of H2 consumption throughout conversion to H2O during reactions with lattice oxygen from surfaces. 20 mg of catalyst was used, and the pretreatment was conducted at 120 °C for 1 h under Ar flow. The content was then cooled to RT. From 30 to 900 °C, the temperature was increased at a rate of 10 °C min−1 while a 10% H2/Ar flow was maintained. The elemental compositions and valence states of elements on the surfaces of materials were observed using a High-Performance X-ray Photoelectron Spectrometer (HP-XPS). The specific surface areas of materials were measured by N2 adsorption at −196 °C, namely via the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller method performed on a volumetric gas adsorption analyzer (BEL Japan Inc., BELSORP-mini II). Analysis of catalyst structure was completed via Raman spectroscopy (inVia Reflex, Renishaw), applying an instrumental measurement range of 200–3000 cm−1, a 532 nm laser, and a 0.5 cm−1 resolution. 2.5 Electrochemical characterization An electrochemical materials study was performed via a combined three-electrode cell system, consisting of a potentiostat (Autolab PGSTAT302N, Metrohm AG), a working electrode comprised of a studied catalyst, a glassy carbon counter electrode, and an Ag/AgCl reference electrode. Prior to use, the glassy carbon surfaces of rotating disk electrodes (surface area = 0.071 cm2) were mechanically polished by alumina slurries to reduce their thicknesses (from 0.5–0.7 μm to 0.03–0.05 μm), yielding mirror-like interfaces. Such surfaces were then washed with mixed ethanol and water solvents, and were finally dried at room temperature. For catalyst ink preparation, 2.5 mg of catalysts were dispersed in a water and ethanol mixture (4:1) with drops (5 µL) of 0.5 wt.% Nafion (Sigma-Aldrich) solution. This was done by continuous sonication, forming a homogeneous ink solution. Next, 5 μL of ink was dropped onto a working electrode surface and dried in air. Prior to starting ORR measurements, the electrode was cleaned for 30 min by electrolyte saturation in a N2 atmosphere. Then, CV voltammograms were taken of yielded catalysts in an O2-saturated electrolyte, which are compared with corresponding commercial 20 wt.% Pt/C catalyst reference measurements. All CV measurements and linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves were respectively recorded at scan rates of 50 and 10 mV s−1 in 0.1 M KOH solution. Preceding each ORR test, O2 was purged from KOH electrolytes for at least 30 min. The number of electrons transferred during ORR was deduced from LSVs over varying rotation speeds (400–2400 r min−1), namely within an operating potential window from −0.8 to +0.2 V. The stabilities and methanol tolerances of studied catalysts were examined at an applied potential of ∼0.66 V by chronoamperometric measurements under an O2 atmosphere, following the US Department of Energy protocol. Electron transfer number (n) values were calculated using the Koutecky–Levich (K-L) equations (Eqs. (1) and (2)) [26]. (4) H 2 O 2 % = 200 × I R / N I D + I R / N (5) n = 4 × I D I D + I R / N 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Morphological and structural characterization Here, we demonstrate efficiently-stabilized heterostructures composed of 2D / 2D-coupled layers of NiO and mesoporous NG nanosheets (Fig. S1). These layered structures induce growth of nano-sized Fe2O3. Such layering accounts for enriched surface defect sites, which uniquely link mesostructure with microstructure in a Fe2O3@NiO / NG catalyst. Field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM) revealed crumpled NG conformations, composed of wrinkled sites and edges, were caused by folded surfaces. Such conformations provide suitable defect sites from the greater N-doping of graphene backbones relative to pristine graphene oxide (GO) sheets without impurities (Fig. S2a–d). Scheme 1 illustrates a 2D / 2D mesoporous network of NG-coupled NiO nanosheets, supported by shelled and holey Fe2O3 NCs (Fe2O3@NiO / NG). These catalysts are synthesized by initial hydrothermal alkalization followed by annealing and further chemical-etching treatments (Supplementary Information: Experimental Methods and Scheme 1). Homogeneous alkalization of Ni(II) and Fe(II) solutions at low temperature can promote adsorption of iron and nickel (Ni x +, Fe x +, x ∈ (2, 3)) ions on NG surfaces. Generally, hydrothermal reactions at high pressures activate reactant species at super-saturation points. This activation leads to instantaneous formation of ultrafine Ni and Fe reaction intermediates. Both kinetic and thermodynamic factors favor metal (Ni, Fe) hydroxide formation as dominant reaction intermediates [27,28] during such hydrothermal alkalization reactions (Figs. S3 and S4, Eqs. (6) and (7)). (6) N a O H → N a + + O H - (7) M 2 + + 2 O H - → M ( O H ) 2 M = N i , F e Ni(OH)2 / Fe(OH)2 NCs, in conjunction with NG nanosheets, spontaneously self-assemble to form layered structures. This process occurs as a result of the synergistic effects of their chemical interconnections, as is reinforced by oriented attachment kinetics [28,29]. The 2D anisotropic growth of Ni(OH)2 nanosheets encourages the accumulation of nanostructures in alkaline media. Given their intrinsic lamellar properties [1], such nanostructures have gauze-like morphologies (Fig. S4). Finally, calcination at 400 °C yields complete decomposition of Ni(OH)2 to consistent sheet-like NiO nanostructures [Ni(OH)2 → NiO + H2O] [1]. Therefore, a stable mesoporous 2D / 2D heterostructure (Fig. 1 a and Fig. S5) is obtained without damaged or broken components, even after annealing. Mesoporous carbon layers were homogenously immobilized on the heterojunction interfaces of NiO / NG layers, as confirmed by the uniform distributions of Ni, C, N, and O elements (Fig. S5d–h). These ultrathin micron-sized nanosheets were uniformly arranged in various orientations. However, some of these nanosheets are comprised of rough surfaces, possibly as a result of grain boundaries and surface defects (Fig. S5a–c). Such defect structures could improve interfacial porosity by accretion of holey Fe2O3 NCs in the edges of NiO / NG matrices. The existence of Fe2O3 NCs within layered heterojunction interfaces of NiO / NG nanosheets could overcome the irreversible restacking of individual nanosheets. This claim is supported by the observed strong attachment of Fe2O3 NCs within the layered heterosurfaces of NiO / NG nanosheets by electrostatic and coordination interactions (Fig. S6a–c). Previous literature indicates that point defects on supportive surfaces are bonded to various metal oxides, and bind catalytically active adsorbates by metal-adsorbate electrostatic interactions. The strength of such binding can be controlled by the effect of oxidation state on metal coordination [24,30]. Such defect engineering can be generalized to the currently studied Fe2O3@NiO / NG, namely through modifying effective oxidation states of catalytically active metals by adjusting Fe/Ni ratios of relevant structures (later shown through XRD results). FESEM images depict the growth of Fe2O3 NCs on NiO / NG layered interfaces (Fig. 1b and c and Fig. S6a–c), and how they develop efficient porous hybrids of NG-coupled 2D NiO-shelled holey Fe2O3 NCs (Fe2O3@Ni / NG) for active catalysts. Fig. 1(d) illustrates the structure of Fe2O3@NiO / NG, wherein Fe2O3 NCs were shelled by 2D / 2D mesoporous networks of NG-coupled NiO nanosheets. Although our simulation models are not exactly the same as TEM images due to the computational costs, it is enough to explain the effect of heterojunction structures of NiO / NG and Fe2O3 / NiO on the ORR electrocatalytic performance, which was observed in our TEM images. Across the complete heterostructure morphology, both supports (NiO and NG) are strongly induced to improve hierarchical porous architectures via interconnected NiO and NG layers. FE-SEM images show that Fe2O3 NCs have diameters of 20–25 nm (Fig. 1c, inset) and may effectively prevent nanosheet aggregation. Remarkably, prominent wrinkles span entire Fe2O3@NiO / NG nanostructure surfaces; this may be due to effective strain, which produces wrinkles to resist compression. The energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) elemental analysis of Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrids was determined to have an approximate 1.66/1 final weight ratio of Fe/Ni after acid leaching (Fig. 1e). This analysis identified significant losses of impurities, possibly because of acid treatment (Fig. S7). The atomic ratio of Fe/Ni was determined to be about 2/1 from the results of ICP-AES analyses (Table S1), which is in good agreement with X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) outcomes (detailed study in XPS analysis; Table S2). This synthesis step strongly increases catalytic activity by minimizing impurity effects. Therefore, the unstacked 2D frameworks (NiO / NG) of Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrids can feature high micropore and mesopore densities with good dispersity [4,28]. Such pores are largely located on nanosheet surface edges, and within the interiors of nanosheets wrapped around Fe2O3. Concurrently, oxygen defects were evidenced (Fig. S8 ) via H2-TPR, and further explained in XPS spectra, by introducing the Fe2O3 and NiO nanostructures on NG support basal planes. This results in higher oxygen vacancies within Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrids [21,31]. Elemental color mappings (Fig. S9) also reveal the homogenous distributions of C, N, O, Ni, and Fe in Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrids. Thus, defect-enriched mesoporous heterostructures of NG-coupled, NiO-encapsulated holey Fe2O3 (Fe2O3@NiO / NG) can maximize active site concentrations. This maximization occurs by active site exposure on the unique basal planes of 2D / 2D matrices [21,32], which are encompassed by Fe2O3 NCs. The structural evolution of the synthesized hybrids was confirmed by X-ray diffraction (XRD) spectra. The α-Fe2O3 crystal phases in Fe2O3 / NG hybrids (Fig. 1f) yield XRD 2θ peaks at ∼33.0°, ∼35.5°, ∼40.8°, and ∼43.5°. These respectively correspond to (104), (110), (113) and (202) diffraction planes [33,34]. During Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrid synthesis, calcination is mainly responsible for the formation of the most dominant iron oxide (Fe2O3) α-phase (JCPDS No. 33‐0664) [33,35] of studied bimetallic oxides (Fe2O3@NiO), converting metal hydroxides to metal oxides (Fig. 1f and Fig. S3). The dominance of such conversion is ensured by significant resistance of Fe species to acidic corrosion [36]. In Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrids (Fig. 1e), NiO (Ni2+) integration into Fe2O3 crystals does not alter crystal faceting. The similar atomic radii of Fe3+ and Ni2+ ions preclude lattice mismatch, thus resulting in interfacial faceting [9,13]. Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrids exhibit stronger and sharper peaks than Fe2O3 / NG hybrids; this difference suggests the presence of NiO-assembled Fe2O3 (Fe2O3@NiO) heterostructures, which are more crystalline than Fe2O3 / NG. Therefore, Fe2O3@NiO heterostructures in Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrids may be developed by homogeneous confinement of Fe2O3 within the shells of NiO layers (further explained in TEM analysis), namely as a consequence of the chemical instability of Ni-based impurities in acidic environments [37]. This development of heterostructures increases the number of pores in Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrids, as verified by EDS analysis. Therefore, acid leaching might induce the formation of surface pores in nanostructures [13]. Surface defects that develop in the Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrids can include oxygen vacancies (Fig. S8), as well as interstitial oxygen defects. The NiO (012) and Fe2O3 (202) lattice peaks coincide in the Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrid (Fig. 1f). However, HR-TEM analysis (Fig. 2 ) clearly confirms the existence of distinct (012) NiO planes [33], which are represented by a lattice spacing d spacing = 0.21 nm [38,39]. Further, the existence of (002) carbon planes [36] confirms the presence of NG nanosheets in Fe2O3@NiO / NG, Fe2O3 / NG, and NiO / NG hybrids (Fig. 1f). Additionally, possible interactions between NG and NiO layers in Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrids are implied by a leftward shift in their (002) crystal planes (∼25.1°) relative to corresponding (002) NG carbon planes (26.3°), corresponding to elongation of C–C d spacing to 0.354 nm (Fig. 1f and Fig. S10a). Such elongation is accompanied by crystalline Fe2O3 encapsulation in layer-by-layer hybridized nanosheets (NG and NiO / NG). Thereby, Fe2O3 NCs act as strong bridging media that connect with NiO nanosheets and coupled NG supports, constructing porous nanoarchitectures of metal oxides with robust conductive networks of sandwich-like nanosheet (NG / Fe2O3 / NiO) nanostructures [40,41]. These heterostructures have great potential for electrochemical applications. At temperatures >400 °C, Fe2O3@NiO nanostructures are controllably converted to NiFe alloy phases (Fig. S10b). This transition is ascribed to the evolution of excessive gaseous moieties (H2, CO2, and CO) during pyrolysis, which promotes the structural conversion of bimetallic oxides (Fe2O3@NiO) to NiFe alloy nanostructures [42]. Therefore, NiFe-NG alloy nanostructures might lose surface area due to the absence of 2D/2D (NiO / NG) interactions [13,30,34]. Comparative XRD analyses of other hybrids that feature different Ni/Fe ratios confirmed the suitability of the optimal Fe:Ni precursor composition ratio (2:1, Fe2Ni1) for Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrid catalysts (Fig. 1f and Fig. S10c). Thus, the Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrid is an efficient catalyst due to the strong ionic interactions between its Ni+2 (NiO) and Fe3+ (Fe2O3) ions. NiO interaction with Fe2O3 crystal defect sites can shift Fe2O3@NiO / NG electronic bands towards their band gaps. Such shifts improve localized metallic bond character by increasing conduction-valence band overlap and decreasing bandgap [43,44], thereby increasing electrical conductivity of the Fe2O3@NiO / NG heterostructure. TEM and HR-TEM analyses were performed to characterize the 2D porous structures of NiO / NG hybrids (Fig. 2a–c and Fig. S11). Ultrathin 2D NiO layered surfaces are uniformly enveloped by NG layers within large domains [38,45] to yield multilayered mesoporous architectures (Fig. 2a and Fig. S11a–d). Thus, in situ grown NiO nanosheets, which are each several nanometers thick (∼4–8 nm) (Fig. S11c and d), contain numerous mesopores (Fig. S11e and f). Entire NG-layered NiO complexes are composed of well-organized layered constructions, which consist of distinct graphene sheets with mesoporous NiO layers. Aligned NiO nanosheets are uniformly dispersed on smooth 2D NG interfaces (Fig. S12). This dispersion develops layered 2D / 2D (NiO / NG) porous architectures (Fig. 2a–c). HR-TEM images confirm that the interplanar spacing of such NiO layers (d spacing ∼ 0.21 nm) corresponds to the (012) plane. Such layers overlap with lattice-compressed (002) NG carbon planes (d spacing ∼ 0.34 nm) due to the effective interactions between NiO and NG nanosheets (Fig. 2b and c). Consequently, numerous Fe2O3 NCs (∼25 nm) grow on the interfacial junctions of NiO and NG nanosheet surfaces, resulting in layer-by-layer heterostructures (Fig. 2d–k and Fig. S13). These structures possess elongated d spacing (∼0.354 nm) along their (002) carbon planes relative to NiO d spacing values (0.21 nm). Porous Fe2O3@NiO heterostructures are developed by fastening such NCs to these junctions via strong coupling interactions involving NiO and holey Fe2O3 (Figs. S14 and S15). Additional NG matrix interactions ultimately yield highly-stabilized mesoporous Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrids (Fig. 2d and e). HR-TEM images of Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrids depict holey structured Fe2O3 NCs (Fig. 2e) that are adequately wrapped by NG-layered NiO nanosheet surfaces, and confirm the presence of several mesopores (∼2–3 nm) in Fe2O3 NCs (Fig. 2f). The inset of Fig. 2(e) also reveals that porous NG and NiO nanosheets combine with perfect holey Fe2O3 NCs; this process yields efficient mesoporous hybrids by forming Fe2O3 NCs encased in suitably-aligned NG and NiO layers. Corresponding d spacing values of ∼0.25 nm and 0.38 nm refer respectively to the (110) and (012) lattice planes of Fe2O3 within them [46]. Selected area electron diffraction (SAED) patterns illustrate the intersection of NG and NiO shells by highlighting their (002) (d spacing ∼ 0.354 nm) carbon planes and the (012) (d spacing ∼ 0.21 nm) lattice planes of adjacent NiO (inset of Fig. 2g and h). Therefore, each NG and NiO nanosheet undergoes persistent interfacial growth involving effective attachment with Fe2O3. Such growth is facilitated by increasing the inter-planar C–C spacing (NG) of Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrids. Calcination and acid leaching effectively remove metallic impurities from hybrids, creating a number of holes to generate holey Fe2O3 NCs [47]. Such procedures construct mesoporous core–shell heterostructures (Fe2O3@NiO / NG). Furthermore, the detection of (113) (d spacing ∼ 0.22 nm) and (014) (d spacing ∼ 0.27 nm) crystal planes of Fe2O3 (Fig. 2j and k) demonstrates successful NC encapsulation by NG (d spacing ∼ 0.354 nm) layers. This conclusion is also supported by their corresponding SAED patterns (Fig. 2j and k insets). EDS line-maps clearly demonstrate uniform dispersions of Fe2O3 over the surfaces of NG and NiO nanosheets (Fig. 2l). Corresponding elemental color mappings of Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrids were assessed by annular dark field – scanning transmission electron microscopy – energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (ADF-STEM-EDS). These results also reveal significant trapping of Fe2O3 NCs within the shells of combined supports (NG and NiO nanosheets) (Figs. S13 and Fig. S16). These observations further confirm the homogeneous distributions of Fe, O, Ni, C, and N (Fig. 2m–r) elements over entire core–shell heterostructures of Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrids. Core-shell morphologies can greatly improve NiO nanosheet electrical conductivity by ensuring close attachment with NG nanosheets [48]. These morphologies can also increase the hydrophilicity of entire nanostructures by wrapping nanosheets around Fe2O3. This wrapping resultantly reinforces O-O bond polarity [49,50], which significantly influences ORR activity. Therefore, Fe2O3@NiO / NG core–shell hybrids achieve ultra-fast electronic charge transfer by reducing the length of ionic diffusion pathways. Such pathways are networked with specially coupled 2D / 2D (NG / NiO) heterostructure interfaces, which increase electrochemical activity [40]. Raman spectroscopy was used to investigate interfacial structural disorder by exploiting localized surface stress differentials of carbon-based nanostructures to distinguish bonding types (Fig. 3 a). The Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrid showed prominent Raman peaks in the elastic modes of the D band (∼1355 cm−1), G band (∼1579 cm−1), 2D band (∼2709 cm−1), and D + G band (∼2917 cm−1) [4,5]. The D band represents disordered sp 3 bonding phases with defective sites, and the G band represents sp 2-hybridized graphitic carbons. The 2D (∼2709 cm−1) and D + G (∼2917 cm−1) bands are linked to the effective conversion of GO to NG [31]. These results are evidence for increases in defect densities. Ratios of the D band intensity (I D) to G band intensity (I G) quantify the number of large defect densities with disordered graphitic sites. NG had the highest I D / I G ratio (∼1.13) of all compared structures (Fig. 3a); this result suggests more structural defects were introduced into its graphitic network. In contrast, integrating NiO and Fe2O3 into NG networks lowers the I D/I G ratios of Fe2O3 / NG (to 1.09) and NiO / NG (to 1.11); these changes indicate the improvement of structural order. NiO incorporation into Fe2O3 / NG nanostructures induces strong bonding across Fe2O3@NiO heterostructures, and improves structural order in Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrids (I D/I G ∼ 1.08), compared to the more-defective Fe2O3 / NG (I D/I G = 1.09) and NiO/NG (I D / I G ∼ 1.11) hybrids. Structurally-ordered Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrids have large concentrations of oxygen vacancies and other defects [3,7] (Fig. S8), which may increase the number of catalytic ORR sites. G band shifting also confirms strong interactions between NG nanosheets and Fe2O3-NiO heterostructures (Fig. S17). Moreover, the nanostructures studied have additional Raman peaks ranging from ∼300 to ∼800 cm−1 (Fig. 3a, inset). A 1g and F 2g vibrational modes, which correspond to M−O (Fe−O and Ni−O) symmetric and asymmetric stretching bonds, are assigned to peaks at ∼654 and ∼450 cm−1, respectively. Asymmetric metal oxygen bending is linked to the peak at ∼316 cm−1 [50,51]. These peaks result from strong coupling interactions between Fe2O3 and NiO nanostructures of Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrids, and are consistent with XRD and HR-TEM results. N2 adsorption–desorption isotherm (ADI) tests were conducted to confirm the porous structures of as-synthesized hybrids (Fig. 3b). Atomically ultrathin features of NG-layered NiO nanosheets and Fe2O3 NCs (Fe2O3@NiO / NG) contain holes, which can facilitate mass transport of reactants [14,47]. Mesoporous structures were revealed by N2-ADI curves, which display hysteresis loops characteristic of type IV isotherms. Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrids contain abundant mesopores with diameters of ∼2–50 nm. High specific surface areas (SSAs) of Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrids (∼190.12 m2 g−1) are obtained due to the interconnected holey Fe2O3 NCs between consecutive porous 2D nanosheets (NiO / NG: ∼150 m2 g−1). Nano-sized, holey Fe2O3 NCs act as bridges between NG and NiO nanosheets by interfacial bonds, which separate NiO and NG enough to inhibit self-agglomeration (Fe2O3 / NG: ∼102 m2 g−1; NG: 80 m2 g−1). This bonding greatly increases the SSAs of porous Fe2O3@NiO / NG nanostructures [47] and gives them excellent catalytic activity. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed to identify how the different elemental components of as-prepared catalysts affect their electronic structural features. These components encompass variations in the elemental valence states of surface atoms. XPS analysis of Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrids (Fig. S18) demonstrates the presence of Fe (2p), Ni (2p), N (1s), O (1s), and C (1s) elements with corresponding core level spectra (Fig. 3c–f and Fig. S19). The Fe 2p XPS spectrum (Fig. 3c) has major peaks at ∼710 and ∼723.8 eV, which result from spin − orbital interactions involving Fe 2p 3/2 and Fe 2p 1/2 doublets, respectively. The deconvoluted Fe 2p 3/2 core-level spectrum (Fig. 3c) shows satellite features of Fe3+ and Fe2+ cations. These features are located at ∼713.4, ∼710.2, and ∼717.1 eV. Another peak at ∼723.8 eV is assigned to Fe 2p 1/2 orbitals, which is ascribed to Fe3+ cations [46]. The synergistic interaction between Fe and Ni oxides produces a downward shift (∼0.30 eV) in binding energy peaks (Fig. 3c). Therefore, the charge transfer between Fe2O3 and NiO in Fe2O3@NiO-NG hybrids can modify the electronic states of Fe surfaces [13]. This phenomenon may account for high ORR activity and durability. Fig. 3(d) displays deconvoluted Ni 2p spectral doublets separated by ∼17.6 eV, which represent Ni 2p 3/2 and Ni 2p 1/2 satellite peaks. Deconvoluted subset peaks of the Ni 2p 3/2 core–shell spectrum portray the coexistence of metallic Ni and Ni2+/Ni3+ oxidized moieties for both NiO-NG and Fe2O3@NiO-NG hybrids. Two additional peaks connected to Ni3+ (∼872.5 eV) and Ni2+ (∼876.8 eV) valence states can be attributed to Ni 2p 1/2 spin–orbit coupling [7]. Binding energy shifts in Ni 2p spin orbits also correlate with strong synergistic interactions [48], which exist between Fe2O3 and NiO crystals in Fe2O3@NiO-NG hybrids. Successful introduction of N atoms into the carbon backbones of graphitic matrices was confirmed by XPS study (Fig. 3e). High-resolution, multimodal N 1s spectra can be classified by the variously-coordinated N atoms that they represent [4,5]. These configurations include pyridinic N-oxides (at ∼402.4 eV for N), graphitic N (at ∼400.8 eV for N2), pyrrolic N (at ∼399.5 eV for N3), and pyridinic N (at ∼398.1 eV for N4). These different N-moieties critically affect the increase in ORR activity. The core level O 1s spectra of Fe2O3@NiO / NG (Fig. 3f) depict three peaks typical of M−O bonds. The peaks (Fig. 3f) are assigned to lattice oxygen (O2−, ∼530.1 eV), defect sites or oxygen vacancies (∼531.5 eV), and surface-adsorbed oxygen (∼533.1 eV). Thus, Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrids provide high ratios of lattice oxygen to oxygen vacancies, which create additional lattice defects in nanostructures as a consequence [52]. This observation is supported by Raman (Fig. 3a) and TPR studies (Fig. S8), and such results might be responsible for promoting oxygen adsorption and desorption reactions. High-resolution C 1s spectra (Fig. S19a) demonstrate five deconvoluted peaks linked to C=C (∼284.5 eV), C−N (∼285.6 eV), C−O−C (∼286.8 eV), C=O (∼287.9 eV), and COO (∼289 eV) bonds [6]. N doping concentrations in the graphene sheets of Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrid catalysts were ∼6.2% (Table S2). Therefore, N doping could significantly contribute to improving catalytic activity during oxygen reduction. 3.2 Electrocatalytic activity ORR activities of studied catalysts were evaluated by drop-casting procedures, placing catalysts on working electrode surfaces at loadings of ∼0.65 mg cm−2. Three-electrode-system cyclic voltammetry (CV) and LSV (Fig. 4 ) of the catalysts were measured in O2-saturated 0.1 M KOH solutions. The ORR activities of monometallic oxides (NiO and Fe2O3) embedded in NG (NiO / NG, Fe2O3 / NG) were evaluated to compare the effectiveness of the 2D / 2D NG–coupled bimetallic NiO shelled (2D / 2D) holey Fe2O3 (Fe2O3@NiO / NG). Comparison of CV curves in Ar and O2-saturated alkaline solutions (Fig. S20) reveals distinct ORR cathodic peaks for all studied oxide structures [4]. These peaks represent electrochemical reduction processes at interfaces. The best ORR activity was obtained using a particularly composed Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrid (Fe2Ni1) at an optimized temperature (400 °C) (Fig. S21), as confirmed by its strong and positive oxygen electrochemical reduction peak at 0.80 V (vs. RHE) (Fig. S20). Adding monometallic (Ni, Fe) or bimetallic (Fe2O3@NiO) oxides to isolated NG increases its ORR activity, and improves its other material characteristics related to catalysis [5] (Fig. 4a and b and Fig. S20 and S21). Catalyst ORR polarization and voltammetric potential curves (Fig. 4a) corroborate the superior onset potential (0.96 V vs. RHE) and half-wave potential (0.83 V vs. RHE) results for Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrids (Fig. 4b). The high catalytic activity of Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrid is further examined by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) spectra (Fig. S22), which shows a smaller R ct value (∼84.6 Ω) for Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrid than for NiO / NG (∼115.7 Ω) hybrid and Fe2O3 / NG hybrid catalysts (∼148.6 Ω). Fe2O3@NiO / NG features several attributes that are advantageous to ORR catalysis. Brunauer, Emmett and Teller (BET) surface-area analysis (Fig. 3b) confirmed that the NiO and NG components of Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrids strengthen interactions between reactants and surfaces. This effect is a result of the increase of component SSAs from 2D/2D combination, specifically from ∼80 m2 g−1 for isolated NG to 150 m2 g−1 for NiO / NG hybrids. The electronic structures of studied catalyst surfaces are modified by introducing holey Fe2O3, leading to favorable oxygen adsorption. Such favorability is enabled by exposing highly active sites and promoting synergistic interactions between bimetallic oxides and NG supports [21,22]. Tafel plots (Fig. 4c and Fig. S23) confirm the relatively strong ORR activity of Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrids, and their higher electron transfer, larger intrinsic activity, and faster ORR kinetics than other studied catalysts. These plots also indicate that high coverage of reaction intermediates on catalyst surfaces reduces ORR reaction rates by diminishing the exchange of surface oxygen with oxygen from reactants [17]. The Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrid had a lower apparent Tafel slope than Pt/C. This difference serves as evidence of facile reaction kinetics of such oxygen exchange reactions, namely due to increasing oxygen vacancy (VO) concentration ([VO]) in Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrids. This improved [VO] can be attributed to the increase in active site densities [3,18]. This enhancement results from the increased graphitization in NG supports bearing Fe2O3@NiO / NG nanostructures, as well as improved Fe2O3@NiO interactions. Usually, Ni and Fe have slightly higher effective atomic charge magnitudes on pristine surfaces than on defective surfaces. This difference implies that removal of oxygen induces charge accumulation around resulting VO defects [18]. Such accumulation improves the ORR catalytic activity of Fe2O3@NiO / NG, specifically compared to monometallic (Fe2O3 and NiO) surfaces that have lower [VO] [3]. VO formation also results in charge transfer from Fe to Ni. This transfer improves catalytic activity and efficiency [13]. Nevertheless, Fe in Fe2O3@NiO / NG that is responsible for such transfer remains within the cores of studied nanostructures. Maintaining this location enables Fe to enhance the ORR, likely due to the strengthening of Fe-Ni binding throughout ORR redox cycles [20,24,53]. This hypothesis was evaluated by comparing the CV scans of differently controlled Fe2O3@NiO / NG catalysts, all of which were designed to vary over Fe / Ni ratios and temperatures (Fig. S21). Improvement in Fe content increased the bifunctional activity up to a Fe/Ni ratio of 2:1, after which such ORR activity decreased. Therefore, when bimetallic oxide interactions (Fe2O3@NiO) are tuned to optimize core − shell activity, the metal catalyst composition must be considered [13,54]. Furthermore, as Fe concentrations increased, the particle size enlarged and led to particle agglomeration on 2D / 2D (NiO / NG) coupled surfaces. The enlarged particle size and agglomeration also likely reduced nanostructure surface area, and thereby decreased bifunctional ORR activity [36]; this response accounts for the optimized 2:1 Fe/Ni ratio. XRD and HR-TEM analyses (Figs. 1f and 2g–k) showed the distinct separation of various Fe2O3 crystal phases on NiO / NG interfaces. Therefore, nanostructure separation is correlated with increased catalytic performance, and this relationship can be utilized to design Fe2O3@NiO / NG structures with activity matching or superseding that of leading engineered ORR electrocatalysts (Fig. 4c). Rotating-disk voltammetry (RDV) evaluating electrocatalytic ORR kinetic parameters was conducted at a scan rate of 5 mV s−1 and rotation speeds of 400–2400 r min−1 (Fig. 4d and Fig. S24). Within this experimental range, two distinct kinetic regimes were discernable over potential domains. Current density increased from 4.00 to 7.11 mA cm−2 as rotating disk speed was increased from 400 to 2400 r min−1 (Fig. 4d and Fig. S24), which is within the current and thus diffusion-limited regime. A corresponding Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrid K-L plot (Fig. 4e) confirmed a first-order reaction for O2 dissolution. This K-L plot also shows that increasing rotation speeds elevated oxygen flux towards electrode surfaces, and thus increased the currents obtained [55]. Parameters of the fitted K-L equations indicated an average electron transfer number n = 3.97 (Fig. S25) per oxygen molecule (0.6 V vs. RHE). Moreover, RRDE results demonstrate that the H2O2 yield of the Fe2O3@NiO / NG catalyst is approximately 8%–9% during operation within the potential interval of 0.4–0.8 V, and the average n is ∼3.9. This verifies a high 4e− selectivity for the reduction of oxygen to water (Fig. S26). This conclusion verifies that ORR on Fe2O3@NiO / NG uses an efficient four-electron pathway, and its activity is comparable with those of other catalysts that have recently been reported elsewhere (Fig. 4f and Table S3). 3.3 Theoretical interpretation In order to investigate differences in the origins of higher ORR activity of Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrids versus other 2D or 2D/2D catalysts, we performed DFT calculations to plot the relative energy profiles of NG, NiO, NG/NiO, Fe2O3 / NG, Fe2O3/NiO, and NG/Fe2O3/NiO. The details of DFT calculations are included in Supplementary Information. At first, we compared the catalytic activities of pure NG and NiO (Fig. 5a). Oxygen adsorption is more favorable on NiO (–0.63 eV) than NG (−0.17 eV). However, oxygen dissociation is endothermic on NiO (2.03 eV), whereas it is exothermic on NG (−1.75 eV). This implies that NiO is advantageous to molecular oxygen adsorption, but NG is favorable to oxygen dissociation. Therefore, oxygen dissociation activity is significantly increased when NG is introduced to NiO (blue line in Fig. 5b). Surprisingly, oxygen adsorption strength is even further increased by introducing iron oxide to NiO or NG, regardless of the type of support material used (Figs. S32–S35). When iron oxide is introduced to NG (Fe2O3 / NG) and NiO (Fe2O3@NiO), the active sites for O2 adsorption and dissociation are changed to Fe2O3 sites (Figs. S27–S35). Upon the introduction of Fe2O3, the adsorption energy of O2 is enhanced from −0.17 to −2.20 eV on NG and from −0.63 eV to −1.34 eV on NiO, respectively. However, oxygen dissociation becomes significantly less favorable on Fe2O3 / NG (−0.29 eV) compared to pure NG (−1.75 eV). This may be attributed to differences in active sites for oxygen dissociation between NG and Fe2O3 structures, given their relative O2 and O adsorption strengths (Fig. S32a and Table S4). To be an ideal catalyst, both strong adsorption and easier dissociation of O2 are required. In this sense, Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrid catalysts showed balanced energetics for O2 adsorption (−1.27 eV) and dissociation (−1.45 eV). For example, O2 dissociation on Fe2O3@NiO / NG (−1.45 eV) was a bit less favorable than that on NG (−1.75 eV). However, O2 adsorption is much stronger on Fe2O3@NiO / NG (−1.27 eV) than on NG (−0.17 eV). Therefore, the overall activity of the hybrid catalyst is enhanced compared to that of NG. This moderate interaction between oxygen and surface can be a key to designing enhanced catalysts for ORR. In this regard, the trade-offs imposed by the Sabatier rule ensure that excessively strong catalyst-adsorbate binding [14,40] induces necessary initial surface oxidation. However, such bonds cause catalyst over-binding and ultimately poisoning, which decreases long-term activity [56]. In contrast, excessively weak binding energies enable fast desorption of oxygen from active sites, while also diminishing the initial adsorption of reactive species required for oxidation [2]. As a result of this trade-off, intermediate oxygen binding energies (E OB) optimize ORR activity by simultaneously describing initial catalytic surface oxidation and desorption reactions [52]. Thus, modulating E OB, which is a descriptor broadly applied to ORR and other reactions, can tune the electrocatalytic activity of studied Fe2O3@NiO / NG. Therefore, we calculated E OB on iron oxide catalysts with different support materials (Fe2O3 / NG, Fe2O3/NiO, and Fe2O3@NiO / NG). |E OB| increases as the amount of charge transfer from 2D material(s) to Fe2O3 improves (Fig. 5c). This implies that (1) stronger binding energies originate through enhancing charge transfer from 2D material(s) to Fe2O3 (Fig. 5d) and (2) the optimal value of E OB might be more negative than that of Fe2O3@NiO / NG. This tendency is also effective in the relationship between DFT-calculated E OB and experimentally measured Tafel slopes (Fig. 5e): more negative E OB result in lower Tafel slopes. Therefore, we conclude that the reason for the high catalytic activity of Fe2O3@NiO / NG is the closeness of its E OB to the optimal point for ORR. In addition, VO formation is also relatively favorable on Fe2O3@NiO / NG compared to other catalysts (Fig. 5f), and E OB decreases from −1.42 to −1.92 eV on Fe2O3@NiO / NG upon addition of an oxygen vacancy. These theoretical outcomes are in good agreement with our XPS results (Fig. 3f). Since VO can serve as active sites for oxygen adsorption, increased VO concentration improves active site densities [7,17], thereby improving the catalytic activity of ORR. 3.4 Electrochemical stability To determine whether Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrids are effective candidates to supersede commercial Pt/C electrodes in ORR catalysis, we evaluated their electrochemical stability in methanol crossover tests. When catalysts were subjected to 3.0 M methanol/ethanol, the current–time (i-t) chronoamperometric responses for ORR (Fig. S36) were nearly constant with Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrid electrodes, but current sharply decreased with Pt/C electrodes. This observation indicates favorable Fe2O3@NiO / NG selectivity for ORR, and that hybrids have greater tolerance to methanol than Pt/C electrocatalysts. Durability testing (Fig. S37) using a chronoamperometric method at 0.6 V contrasts Fe2O3@NiO / NG and commercial Pt/C electrode capabilities during ORR. After continuous operation for 30,000 s, Fe2O3@NiO / NG catalysts underwent mild current attenuation, whereas Pt/C catalysts underwent major current decay (84% retention). These differences in catalyst durability can be attributed to the core–shell structures of Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrids. Nanostructures with high concentrations of low-coordination atoms are usually less kinetically favorable [57]. Further, nanostructures also generally feature elevated surface energies, and are therefore thermodynamically unstable [58]. This instability induces nanostructure interfaces to change during reactions, with resulting decreases in surface energies [55]. Consistent with this unstable character, Pt nanoparticles on carbon surfaces were easily oxidized under exposure to atmosphere [59], and NiFe alloy nanoparticles (treated at >400 °C, Fig. S10b) oxidized these surfaces more readily than corresponding Fe2O3 crystals attached to NG-coupled NiO nanosheets (Fig. S37). These differences in response can be ascribed to nanosheet morphology, which retains better structural stability upon distortion than corresponding nanoparticle/alloy combinations [60]. Comparably active Pt/C aggregates during reactions, which explains its poor stability during long-term testing. In contrast, Fe2O3@NiO / NG electrocatalysts are more stable than Pt/C over time (Fig. S38), and this trait indicates that Fe2O3@NiO / NG electrocatalysts have practical applications in fabricated ORR catalytic films. To help reveal the connection between catalytic stability and morphology, FESEM and XRD were conducted on studied catalysts (Fig. S39) to evaluate ORR cycling stability over 2,000 cycles. SEM imaging showed no apparent morphological changes in Fe2O3@NiO / NG catalysts; this result is consistent with the premise that small and relatively confined Fe2O3 NCs interacted with NiO and mesoporous NG layers. However, some Ni leaching occurred during stability testing, as evidenced by EDX results with greater decreases in Ni than Fe content likely due to NiO shell presence (inset of Fig. S39b). XRD patterns (Fig. S39c) also demonstrated long-term stability of Fe2O3 NCs in Fe2O3@NiO/NG catalysts, which further exhibit well-retained crystallinity and electrocatalytic durability. All of these observations verify the stability of the Fe2O3@NiO / NG catalyst. 3.5 Catalytic reaction mechanism for Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrid In alkaline (KOH) media, a likely mechanism responsible for catalyzing Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrid ORR activity entails several steps. Initially, defects on the Fe2O3@NiO interface interact with their encompassing N-doped graphitic carbon shells. Ultimately, this mechanism yields doubled shells of NiO / NG around Fe2O3 surfaces (Fig. S40). These multilayered, bimetallic-oxide-heterostructure interfaces favorably stabilize needed reaction intermediates and otherwise increase electrochemical reduction rates. Molecular orbital modeling of relevant transition metal oxide catalysis indicates that ORR activity is induced by bonding between metal d states and O 2p states [44]. Specifically, the e g orbitals of transition metal ions on catalyst surfaces interact by σ-bonding with the anions of adsorbates. Therefore, eg orbital d-electron filling affects bonding of oxygenated reaction intermediates to catalysts, thereby optimizing catalyst activity [61]. Orbital modeling further indicates that increases in the covalent character of this metal–oxygen bonding is responsible for improvement of ORR activity. Thus, improved ORR activity and durability of Fe2O3@NiO/NG catalysts in alkaline electrolytic media are the results of contributions from several sources. (i) Augmenting covalent M−O bonding character between catalytically active sites and adsorbates, enabling the adsorption of reactants comprised of O and subsequent reaction steps. (ii) Forming 2D/2D support nanostructures, improving catalyst surface area and active site exposure to electrolytes comprised of alkaline media [22,35]. (iii) Engineering Fe-Ni charge transfer to delocalize charge density across Ni, thereby further increasing catalytic activity [4,13,24]. (iv) For Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrids, inducing synergistic effects between N-doped graphene supports and bonded bimetallic oxides (Fe2O3@NiO). This synergy produces M−N interactions that favor charge transport over entire catalysts, expanding beyond readily-exposed active sites. 4 Conclusions In this work, holey Fe2O3 NCs were anchored to supports comprised of NG and 2D NiO nanosheet shells (Fe2O3@NiO / NG). They were designed and synthesized by alkalization, followed by annealing. Multiple structural properties of these catalysts were engineered to yield stable Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrids, namely by developing doubled shells around catalytic Fe2O3 surfaces. Such properties include Fe2O3 NC size, crystal structure attributes, and 2D/2D (NiO / NG) support interaction character. Fe:Ni ratios were modulated to tune the electronic and structural properties of bimetallic heterostructures (Fe2O3@NiO). Experimental and computational analyses determined that local crystalline lattice distortions of bimetallic nanostructured (Fe2O3@NiO) surfaces were connected to Fe and Ni d-band downshifting and decreased intermediate binding energies of the ORR. This downshifting was correlated with increases in electron-transfer rates and ORR kinetics of active sites on studied catalytic surfaces. Comparisons of binding energies obtained using DFT calculations substantiated experimental observations of relatively strong electrocatalytic efficiency for Fe2O3@NiO / NG hybrids. Results achieved in this study provide a direct structure − catalytic correlation, which can be exploited to understand the functional engineering of NG-encapsulated Fe2O3@NiO nanostructures. These conclusions inspire the rational design of multi-functional and cost-effective catalysts for many applications. coredata.dc:description: As a noble metal substitute, two-dimensional (2D) hierarchical nano-frame structures have attracted great interest as candidate catalysts due to their remarkable advantages – high intrinsic activity, high electron mobility, and straightforward surface functionalization. Therefore, they may replace Pt-based catalysts in oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) applications. Herein, a simple method is developed to design hierarchical nano-frame structures assembled via 2D NiO and N-doped graphene (NG) nanosheets. This procedure can yield nanostructures that satisfy the criteria correlated with improved electrocatalytic performance, such as large surface area, numerous undercoordinated atoms, and high defect densities. Further, porous NG nanosheet architectures, featuring NiO nanosheets densely coordinated with accessible holey Fe2O3 moieties, can enhance mesoporosity and balance hydrophilicity. Such improvements can facilitate charge transport and expose formerly inaccessible reaction sites, maximizing active site density utilization. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations reveal favored O2 adsorption and dissociation on Fe2O3 hybrid structures when supported by 2D NiO and NG nanomaterials, given 2D materials donated charge to Fe2O3 active sites. Our systematic studies reveal that synergistic contributions are responsible for enriching the catalytic activity of Fe2O3@NiO / NG in alkaline media – encompassing internal voids and pores, unique hierarchical support structures, and concentrated N-dopant and bimetallic atomic interactions. Ultimately, this work expands the toolbox for designing and synthesizing highly efficient 2D / 2D shelled functional nanomaterials with transition metals, endeavoring to benefit energy conversion and related ORR applications.

coredata.dc:title: Boosting the catalytic activity toward oxygen reduction via a heterostructure of porous iron oxide-decorated 2D NiO/NG nanosheets
